tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating final velocities using the Tsiolkovsky rocket equation and understanding the relationship between specific impulse, mass flow rate, and burn time. It involves multiple steps and the integration of rocket propulsion concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: With gravity and aerodynamic forces neglected, the motion is governed by the ideal rocket equation. Both missiles have the same specific impulse and the same initial mass. The propellant mass consumed is \(m_p = \dot{m} t_b\). For A: \(m_{p,A} = 120 \times 30 = 3600\,\text{kg}\), so \(M_{f,A} = 5600 - 3600 = 2000\,\text{kg}\). For B: \(m_{p,B} = 70 \times 70 = 4900\,\text{kg}\), so \(M_{f,B} = 5600 - 4900 = 700\,\text{kg}\). The burnout velocities are \(V_A = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(5600/2000)\) and \(V_B = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(5600/700)\). Taking the ratio, the common factor \(g_0 I_{sp}\) cancels: \(V_A/V_B = \ln(2.8)/\ln(8) \approx 1.0296/2.0794 \approx 0.495 \approx 0.5\). Hence \(V_A \approx 0.5 V_B\), which matches option C.

step_by_step: Step 1: Note that gravity and aerodynamic forces are neglected, so the ideal rocket equation applies: \(V_b = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(M_i/M_f)\).
Step 2: Compute propellant mass consumed by each missile using \(m_p = \dot{m} t_b\). For A: \(m_{p,A} = 120 \times 30 = 3600\,\text{kg}\). For B: \(m_{p,B} = 70 \times 70 = 4900\,\text{kg}\).
Step 3: Find final (burnout) masses: \(M_{f,A} = 5600 - 3600 = 2000\,\text{kg}\); \(M_{f,B} = 5600 - 4900 = 700\,\text{kg}\). Initial mass for both is \(M_i = 5600\,\text{kg}\).
Step 4: Write burnout velocities using the rocket equation: \(V_A = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(5600/2000)\), \(V_B = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(5600/700)\).
Step 5: Take the ratio to eliminate unknown \(g_0 I_{sp}\): \(V_A/V_B = \ln(5600/2000)/\ln(5600/700) = \ln(2.8)/\ln(8)\).
Step 6: Evaluate numerically: \(\ln(2.8) \approx 1.0296\), \(\ln(8) \approx 2.0794\), so \(V_A/V_B \approx 1.0296/2.0794 \approx 0.495 \approx 0.5\). Therefore, \(V_A = 0.5 V_B\).

topic.name: Rocket performance and rocket equation
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 6 Propulsion -> Rocket propulsion, rocket equation, performance

concepts.name: Effect of burn time when gravity is neglected

essential: Newton\'s second law and momentum conservation for variable-mass systems
Definition and use of the ideal rocket equation
Concept of specific impulse and its role in rocket performance
Understanding of mass flow rate and burn time
helpful: Physical interpretation of mass ratio in rockets
Difference between ideal and real rocket performance (gravity and drag losses)

Main Concept: requires: Newtonian mechanics for rockets (variable mass systems)
requires: Definition of specific impulse and exhaust velocity
requires: Ability to compute mass ratio from mass flow and burn time
enables: Design and comparison of rocket stages and trajectories
enables: Optimization of propellant mass and staging strategies

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that specific impulse and g0 cancel in the ratio
Requires careful computation of propellant mass from mass flow and time
Students may be distracted by different burn durations and think they directly set velocity

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson Jr.
textbook_references.text_snippet: The solution yields the rocket equation: \(V_b = g_0 I_{sp} \ln(M_i / M_f)\). The burnout velocity is directly proportional to the specific impulse and the natural logarithm of the mass ratio.

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson Jr.
textbook_references.text_snippet: The rocket equation is a mathematical relationship that connects the change in velocity (delta-v) of a rocket to its specific impulse (Isp), initial mass (Mi), and final mass (Mf).

video_references.topic_covered: Tsiolkovsky rocket equation and burnout velocity including gravity losses

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Compute propellant mass and final mass for each rocket \u2192 Apply rocket equation \u2192 Take ratio of velocities to cancel common factors \u2192 Evaluate numerically
key_insights: When gravity and drag are neglected, burn duration does not appear explicitly in the rocket equation; only mass ratio matters.
Same specific impulse and same initial mass mean the velocity ratio depends solely on the two final masses.
Taking the ratio of velocities is an efficient way to avoid needing the actual value of specific impulse.

formulas_principles.name: Ideal rocket equation (Tsiolkovsky)
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when thrust is the dominant force and gravity and aerodynamic drag are neglected or already accounted for separately.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute burnout velocity from mass ratio and specific impulse.

formulas_principles.name: Propellant mass from mass flow rate
formulas_principles.conditions: Constant mass flow rate over the burn duration.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to find how much propellant each missile consumes from the given mass flow and burn time.

formulas_principles.name: Final mass after burnout
formulas_principles.conditions: Single-stage rocket with no mass jettison other than propellant.
formulas_principles.relevance: Needed to compute the mass ratio for the rocket equation.

formulas_principles.name: Ratio of burnout velocities
formulas_principles.conditions: Both rockets have same specific impulse and same initial mass, and gravity/drag neglected.
formulas_principles.relevance: Allows comparison of velocities without knowing numerical value of specific impulse.

industry_examples: Preliminary sizing of tactical missiles where designers compare different grain geometries (which change mass flow and burn time) but want to know the effect on burnout velocity.
Trade studies for launch vehicle upper stages where different propellant loading and burn schedules are compared using mass ratios and the rocket equation.
specific_systems: Solid rocket motors used in surface-to-air missiles, where burn profile (high thrust short burn vs. low thrust long burn) is tailored but overall delta-v depends on mass ratio and Isp.
Boosters on launch vehicles (e.g., Space Shuttle SRBs) where performance estimates use the rocket equation with measured propellant masses.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding that, in the ideal case, only mass ratio and specific impulse determine velocity helps engineers focus on mass optimization and propellant choice, while recognizing that burn time mainly affects gravity losses and structural loads in real missions.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that the missile with higher thrust (higher mass flow rate) must have higher final velocity, ignoring the total propellant mass and mass ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students intuitively associate higher thrust with higher speed, forgetting that with no gravity or drag, only total impulse (or mass ratio) matters for final velocity.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always compute the total propellant mass and mass ratio first, then apply the rocket equation. Remember that thrust affects acceleration profile, not the ideal delta-v directly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing options where the shorter, more powerful burn is assumed to give higher velocity, which is wrong here.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to compute final mass correctly and using the mass flow rate directly in the rocket equation instead of mass ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: In a rush, they plug given numbers into any familiar formula without checking dimensional consistency.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write down the chain: \(\dot{m} \rightarrow m_p = \dot{m} t_b \rightarrow M_f = M_i - m_p \rightarrow M_i/M_f\). Check units at each step.
common_mistakes.consequence: Produces incorrect mass ratios and therefore wrong velocity ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking burn duration appears explicitly in the ideal rocket equation and trying to use \(V = a t\) or \(V = (T/M) t\) directly.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between constant-mass kinematics and variable-mass rocket motion.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that for rockets, mass decreases during burn; use the derived rocket equation rather than constant-mass kinematics.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives qualitatively and quantitatively wrong dependence on time and thrust.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not noticing that specific impulse is the same for both missiles and failing to cancel \(g_0 I_{sp}\) when taking the velocity ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They try to compute absolute velocities, which requires an extra unknown, instead of using a ratio.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: When comparing two similar systems, always look for common factors that cancel in ratios to simplify the problem.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and may lead to stuck calculations if \(I_{sp}\) is not given numerically.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: RIM: Rocket speed depends on Isp and Mass ratio (not on thrust directly in ideal case).
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that ideal rocket delta-v is set by specific impulse and mass ratio.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when deciding which parameters affect burnout velocity in ideal rocket problems.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: 3M chain: Mass flow \u2192 Mass burnt \u2192 Mass ratio.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Sequence to go from \(\dot{m}\) and time to the mass ratio for the rocket equation.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever mass flow rate and burn time are given instead of propellant mass directly.

flashcards.front: Write the ideal rocket equation relating burnout velocity to specific impulse and mass ratio.
flashcards.back: The ideal rocket equation is: \(V_b = g_0 I_{sp} \ln\left(\dfrac{M_i}{M_f}\right)\), where \(M_i\) is initial mass and \(M_f\) is final mass after burnout.

flashcards.front: Two rockets have same \(I_{sp}\) and same initial mass. Rocket 1 burns 3000 kg of propellant, Rocket 2 burns 4500 kg. Which has higher burnout velocity and why?
flashcards.back: Rocket 2 has higher burnout velocity because its mass ratio \(M_i/M_f\) is larger. With same \(I_{sp}\), \(V_b \propto \ln(M_i/M_f)\), so burning more propellant (lower \(M_f\)) increases \(V_b\).

flashcards.front: In the ideal rocket equation (no gravity, no drag), does burn duration appear explicitly? Explain briefly.
flashcards.back: No. The ideal rocket equation only involves \(I_{sp}\) and the mass ratio \(M_i/M_f\). Burn duration affects how quickly velocity is gained, but not the final delta-v if gravity and drag are neglected.

flashcards.front: Common trap: Higher thrust always means higher final velocity. True or false for ideal rockets with same \(I_{sp}\) and total propellant mass?
flashcards.back: False. For ideal rockets with the same \(I_{sp}\) and same total propellant mass (same mass ratio), final delta-v is the same regardless of thrust profile; thrust only changes the acceleration vs. time.

flashcards.front: Given \(\dot{m} = 50\,\text{kg/s}\) and burn time 40 s, initial mass 5000 kg, find final mass after burnout.

real_world_context.application: Design of solid rocket motors for missiles and launch vehicles
real_world_context.industry_example: In tactical missiles, engineers may choose between a high-thrust short-burn motor (for quick acceleration) and a lower-thrust long-burn motor (for extended powered flight). Both can be designed to have similar delta-v if mass ratio and \(I_{sp}\) are matched.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Misunderstanding the role of mass ratio vs. thrust can lead to suboptimal designs that either waste propellant or fail to meet mission velocity requirements.

real_world_context.application: Preliminary performance estimation for upper stages in space launchers
real_world_context.industry_example: Upper stages like those on Ariane or Falcon rockets are sized using the rocket equation to ensure sufficient delta-v for orbit insertion, based on propellant mass and engine \(I_{sp}\).
real_world_context.why_it_matters: An incorrect estimate of required mass ratio can cause a payload shortfall or mission failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a direct rocket equation problem: quickly compute propellant masses, final masses, then use the velocity ratio to avoid needing \(I_{sp}\). This is a fast 2-mark question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that missile B burns more total propellant (higher mass ratio), so it must have higher velocity; thus \(V_A < V_B\). Eliminate options where \(V_A \ge V_B\) and choose the remaining one with \(V_A\) smaller.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute for mass calculations, 1 minute for rocket equation ratio and approximate logs.

search_keywords: burnout velocity mass ratio specific impulse
effect of mass flow rate vs burn time on rocket performance
Anderson Introduction to Flight rocket equation
solid rocket motor mass flow and thrust

alternative_methods.name: Impulse-based reasoning
alternative_methods.description: Instead of directly using the rocket equation, reason that the change in momentum equals the integral of thrust over time. With constant \(I_{sp}\), thrust is proportional to mass flow rate, and total impulse depends on total propellant mass. Then connect total impulse to delta-v via average mass, leading back to a dependence on mass ratio.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Builds physical intuition about impulse and momentum. Cons: More algebraic steps and less straightforward than using the standard rocket equation.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful for conceptual understanding or when teaching the origin of the rocket equation from basic principles.

alternative_methods.name: Differential equation from Newton's law
alternative_methods.description: Start from \(T = M \frac{dV}{dt}\) and \(T = g_0 I_{sp} \dot{m}\), with \(\dot{m} = -dM/dt\). Combine to form \(-g_0 I_{sp} \frac{dM}{M} = dV\), then integrate between initial and final masses to derive the rocket equation and then the velocity ratio.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Shows full derivation and reinforces variable-mass dynamics. Cons: Overkill for a quick exam problem; more time-consuming.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When you need to re-derive or deeply understand the rocket equation rather than just apply it.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: The rocket equation is used to estimate delta-v requirements for orbital insertion, escape trajectories, and interplanetary missions.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Delta-v budgets for orbital maneuvers (Hohmann transfers, plane changes) rely on the rocket equation to translate required velocity changes into propellant mass.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Thrust profiles (mass flow vs. time) affect acceleration and attitude control, even if ideal delta-v depends only on mass ratio.
connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Specific impulse is related to exhaust velocity, which depends on combustion temperature, molecular weight, and nozzle expansion, all rooted in thermodynamics and gas dynamics.

deeper_dive_topics: Gravity and drag losses in real rocket trajectories and modified burnout velocity equations
Staging strategies and how mass ratio multiplies across stages
Internal ballistics of solid rocket motors and how grain geometry shapes mass flow rate vs. time
Optimization of specific impulse vs. thrust-to-weight for different mission profiles

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Rocket propulsion, rocket equation, performance parameters
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent alignment with core rocket performance outcomes; tests direct application of the rocket equation and understanding of mass ratio without unnecessary complexity.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided Anderson\'s derivation and explanation of the rocket equation and a worked burnout velocity example, plus a video note on burnout velocity with gravity losses. These directly support the core concept needed. The question neglects gravity, so only the basic rocket equation from RAG was required; internal knowledge was used to tailor it to this idealized case.

future_questions_potential: Extend the problem to include gravity losses for vertical ascent using the modified burnout velocity equation with thrust-to-weight ratio.
Ask for the specific impulse given one missile\'s final velocity and mass data, then compare with another configuration.
Introduce aerodynamic drag and ask for a qualitative comparison of which burn profile (short/high thrust vs long/low thrust) suffers more losses.
Design a two-stage version of these missiles and compute overall delta-v using the rocket equation for each stage.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text:
Two missiles A and B powered by solid rocket motors have identical specific impulse, liftoff mass of 5600 kg each, and burn durations of t_A = 30 s and t_B = 70 s, respectively. The propellant mass flow rates, ṁ_A and ṁ_B, for missiles A and B, respectively, are given by
ṁ_A = 120 kg/s, 0 ≤ t ≤ 30
ṁ_B = 70 kg/s, 0 ≤ t ≤ 70
Neglecting gravity and aerodynamic forces, the relationship between the final velocities V_A and V_B of missiles A and B, respectively, is given by
